rows.title: One thing today

transcript.eng:
Close your eyes and think about the day. 

Name one thing that you are grateful for. 
Name one thing that you did well. 
Name one thing that you love.

Well done, you are a hero!

rows.transcript:
Close your eyes and think about the day. 

Name one thing that you are grateful for. 
Name one thing that you did well. 
Name one thing that you love.

Well done, you are a hero!

text_1.eng: Caring for yourself is so essential. When you know how you feel, you can see what you need.

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: Wonderful, I am so happy things are going well. Keep up the good work.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: We all have better and worse days. The fact that you are here shows courage and commitment!

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: Sorry that things are difficult now. It is completely normal to struggle sometimes. Remember that you are not alone!

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Today’s lesson is about giving instructions that work!
How we give instructions matters – children are more likely to listen when we say what we want them to do, not what not to do.
Instead of “Don’t touch that!”, try: “Please only touch things that belong to us.”

media_title.eng: Tap play to learn how giving positive instructions can help you and your family

media_transcript.eng:
Greetings everyone.

Let’s try something: Don’t think about a pink elephant…
What did you think about? A pink elephant?

The same happens when we give negative instructions to our children. When we tell them “stop fighting” or “stop playing with your food”, they don’t know how to think about what we DO want them to do, only what we DON’T want them to do.”

When you give a positive instruction, your child is more likely to follow it.

rows.media_transcript:
Greetings everyone.

Let’s try something: Don’t think about a pink elephant…
What did you think about? A pink elephant?

The same happens when we give negative instructions to our children. When we tell them “stop fighting” or “stop playing with your food”, they don’t know how to think about what we DO want them to do, only what we DON’T want them to do.”

When you give a positive instruction, your child is more likely to follow it.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let’s see how @data.characters.f1_father.name gives instructions to @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name:

text_2.eng: @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name is playing with the blocks on the floor.

character_1_text.eng: It looks like you’re having a lot of fun, @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name. It’s almost time to clean up. In 3 minutes, please put your blocks away.

rows.text_1_facilitator: Let’s see how @data.characters.f1_father.name gives instructions to @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name:
rows.text_2: @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name is playing with the blocks on the floor.
rows.character_1_text: It looks like you’re having a lot of fun, @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name. It’s almost time to clean up. In 3 minutes, please put your blocks away.

character_1_text.eng: 3 minutes are over, @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name. Please pack away your blocks.

rows.character_1_text: 3 minutes are over, @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name. Please pack away your blocks.

character_1_text.eng: Thank you very much for packing away the blocks when I asked you, @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name. Because you listened so well, I will read you an extra story before bed.

rows.character_1_text: Thank you very much for packing away the blocks when I asked you, @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name. Because you listened so well, I will read you an extra story before bed.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let’s reflect on what we can learn from @data.characters.f1_father.name and his daughter, @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name.

text_2.eng:
@data.characters.f1_father.name did a few things to help his daughter follow instructions:

- 🤝🏾 Connect with @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name by saying her name and praising her, BEFORE giving an instruction
- 🗺️ Give one instruction at a time
- ⚠️ Give a transition warning (_"in 3 minutes, please put your blocks away"_) 
- 📘 Follow through with a positive consequence (read an extra story)

quiz_1_question.eng: What steps does @data.characters.f1_father.name take to help @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name follow her instruction?

quiz_1_option_1_text.eng: He warns @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name that misbehaviour is not acceptable

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: Try again! @data.characters.f1_father.name actually gives a positive instruction by telling @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name what she should do rather than shouldn’t do. This will help @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name to follow the instruction.

quiz_1_option_2_text.eng: He gives @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name a transition warning and follows through with what he said

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: Correct! These steps make it more likely that @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name follows @data.characters.f1_father.name’s instruction. He also praises his daughter.

quiz_1_option_3_text.eng: He makes @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name feel guilty for taking too long

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: Try again! Making her feel guilty will make @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name less motivated to follow instructions both now and in the future. It will also feel stressful for @data.characters.f1_father.name.

quiz_1_option_4_text.eng: He tells her to stop playing and start cleaning

quiz_1_feedback_4.eng: Try again! He gives @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name a positive instruction to “clean up” without giving a negative one of “stop playing.”

rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: Try again! @data.characters.f1_father.name actually gives a positive instruction by telling @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name what she should do rather than shouldn’t do. This will help @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name to follow the instruction.

rows.text_2:
@data.characters.f1_father.name did a few things to help his daughter follow instructions:

- 🤝🏾 Connect with @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name by saying her name and praising her, BEFORE giving an instruction
- 🗺️ Give one instruction at a time
- ⚠️ Give a transition warning (_"in 3 minutes, please put your blocks away"_) 
- 📘 Follow through with a positive consequence (read an extra story)
rows.quiz_1_option_4_text: He tells her to stop playing and start cleaning
rows.quiz_1_feedback_4: Try again! He gives @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name a positive instruction to “clean up” without giving a negative one of “stop playing.”

text_1_facilitator.eng:
We saw that @data.characters.f1_father.name first connected with his daughter by saying her name, getting down to her level, and giving her praise. This put him in the best position to then give @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name an instruction.

Let's think about what would happen if things went differently.

quiz_1_question.eng: What would have happened if @data.characters.f1_father.name had said: “@data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name, stop playing with your blocks, and don’t go to bed with dirty teeth!”

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: Exactly. It is important to give one positive instruction at a time. It makes a big difference.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: Try again! It’s important to give one positive instruction at a time. This will make the instruction easier to follow.

rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: Exactly. It is important to give one positive instruction at a time. It makes a big difference.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: Try again! It’s important to give one positive instruction at a time. This will make the instruction easier to follow.
rows.quiz_1_question: What would have happened if @data.characters.f1_father.name had said: “@data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name, stop playing with your blocks, and don’t go to bed with dirty teeth!”

We saw that @data.characters.f1_father.name first connected with his daughter by saying her name, getting down to her level, and giving her praise. This put him in the best position to then give @data.characters.f1_daughter_2.name an instruction.

Let's think about what would happen if things went differently.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let’s look at another family to see how positive instructions can help to prevent problems before they start!

text_2.eng: @data.characters.f2_grandfather.name is working in the garden while his granddaughter, @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name, and grandson, @data.characters.f2_son_8.name, are playing with a ball:

rows.text_1_facilitator: Let’s look at another family to see how positive instructions can help to prevent problems before they start!
rows.text_2: @data.characters.f2_grandfather.name is working in the garden while his granddaughter, @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name, and grandson, @data.characters.f2_son_8.name, are playing with a ball:

character_1_text.eng: @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name and @data.characters.f2_son_8.name come and help me plant these vegetables together.

rows.character_1_text: @data.characters.f2_daughter_3.name and @data.characters.f2_son_8.name come and help me plant these vegetables together.

character_1_text.eng: Thank you for coming to help me. We are going to grow lots of delicious vegetables together.

rows.character_1_text: Thank you for coming to help me. We are going to grow lots of delicious vegetables together.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let’s reflect on what @data.characters.f2_grandfather.name did here.

quiz_1_question.eng: What does @data.characters.f2_grandfather.name do to prevent the argument from getting out of hand?

quiz_1_option_1_text.eng: He involves them in a positive activity and gives them praise

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: That’s right. He quickly intervenes to distract them, and gives a positive instruction to redirect them to a positive behaviour.

quiz_1_option_2_text.eng: He reminds them it’s important to get along

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: Try again! @data.characters.f2_grandfather.name gives the children a positive instruction to redirect them to a positive behaviour.

quiz_1_option_3_text.eng: He gives them a warning for a consequence

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: Try again! @data.characters.f2_grandfather.name gives the children a positive instruction to redirect them to a positive behaviour.

quiz_2_question.eng: What would have happened if @data.characters.f2_grandfather.name had not paid attention to the children?

quiz_2_option_1_text.eng: They would have continued to argue

quiz_2_feedback_1.eng:
Yes. The situation between the children would have gotten out of hand. 
These are all correct answers!

quiz_2_option_2_text.eng: They could have hurt each other in the argument

quiz_2_feedback_2.eng:
Yes. The children could have gotten so upset that they would have hurt each other. 
These are all correct answers!

quiz_2_option_3_text.eng: @data.characters.f2_grandfather.name would have had to stop working in the garden

quiz_2_feedback_3.eng:
Yes. If @data.characters.f2_grandfather.name had kept quiet, he would have had to spend more time and energy trying to resolve the conflict. 
These are all correct answers!

rows.quiz_1_feedback_3: Try again! @data.characters.f2_grandfather.name gives the children a positive instruction to redirect them to a positive behaviour.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Here are three tips to give positive instructions that work.

section_1_text.eng:
Say the behaviour you want your child to do.
But before you do that, connect to them, so they are more likely to listen.

section_1_extra_text.eng:
Use your child’s name to get their attention. Go down to their level. Make eye contact.

Then say exactly what you want them to do. For example: “Please take your shoes off when you come inside, dear”.

section_2_text.eng: Give one instruction at a time, and make sure that the instruction is something that your child can do.

section_2_extra_text.eng: Giving a transition warning helps when you are asking them to change activities! For example: “In 10 minutes, you will need to pack away your toys so we can start getting ready for bed.”

section_3_text.eng:
Try using positive words when giving instructions. For example, instead of “Don’t shout inside”, say “Talk in a quiet voice when we’re inside.” 

ALWAYS praise your child immediately when they follow your instruction. This will make them more likely to repeat the behaviour and listen to you next time!

section_3_extra_text.eng:
Give instructions in a firm voice and stay calm. Behave as if you expect your child to do what you ask.

Also, be kind to yourself if you forget sometimes. Learning how to give positive instructions is not easy, but it works!

rows.text_1_facilitator: Here are three tips to give positive instructions that work.
rows.section_1_text:
Say the behaviour you want your child to do.
But before you do that, connect to them, so they are more likely to listen.
rows.section_1_extra_text:
Use your child’s name to get their attention. Go down to their level. Make eye contact.

Then say exactly what you want them to do. For example: “Please take your shoes off when you come inside, dear”.
rows.section_2_text: Give one instruction at a time, and make sure that the instruction is something that your child can do.
rows.section_2_extra_text: Giving a transition warning helps when you are asking them to change activities! For example: “In 10 minutes, you will need to pack away your toys so we can start getting ready for bed.”
rows.section_3_text:
Try using positive words when giving instructions. For example, instead of “Don’t shout inside”, say “Talk in a quiet voice when we’re inside.” 

ALWAYS praise your child immediately when they follow your instruction. This will make them more likely to repeat the behaviour and listen to you next time!
rows.section_3_extra_text:
Give instructions in a firm voice and stay calm. Behave as if you expect your child to do what you ask.

Also, be kind to yourself if you forget sometimes. Learning how to give positive instructions is not easy, but it works!

text_1_facilitator.eng: To practise giving instructions that work, let's try turning our negative instructions into positive ones.

quiz_1_question.eng: Select each option to see how to turn it into a positive instruction:

quiz_1_option_1_text.eng: 🧸 Stop fighting with your siblings over toys!

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: Try saying something like “Please take turns with toys! Each of you can have 5 minutes.”

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: Try saying something like “Please speak with a quiet, indoor voice.”

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: Try saying something like “Please keep your food on the plate.”

quiz_1_feedback_4.eng: Try saying something like “Please only write on paper.”

rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: Try saying something like “Please take turns with toys! Each of you can have 5 minutes.”
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: Try saying something like “Please speak with a quiet, indoor voice.”
rows.quiz_1_feedback_3: Try saying something like “Please keep your food on the plate.”
rows.quiz_1_question: Select each option to see how to turn it into a positive instruction:
rows.quiz_1_option_1_text: 🧸 Stop fighting with your siblings over toys!
rows.text_1_facilitator: To practise giving instructions that work, let's try turning our negative instructions into positive ones.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_4: Try saying something like “Please only write on paper.”

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Ready to give it a go? This week's home activity is to give your child specific, realistic, and positive instructions. 

Remember to give one instruction at a time and praise them. This will help your child to follow your instructions.

media_title.eng: Hear how @data.characters.media_female_3.name learned to give her children positive instructions

media_transcript.eng:
Before, I used to raise my children the way I was raised: I would tell them “don’t do this, don’t do that.” We used to fight a lot, but things have really changed when I learned about giving positive instructions.

Now I focus on the behaviour I want to see, and give clear and simple instructions to my children. It took time to learn to say “please do this” instead of “ don’t do this.” 
My children and even my husband tell me that they love this way of doing things, because now they know what needs to be done. My child said one day “I really love this new mom,” and my own stress levels have come down a lot.

quiz_1_question.eng: Your home activity is to give your child positive instructions. Can you do it?

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: That’s great! It might feel a bit awkward at first, but the more you try, the easier it gets. Keep up the excellent effort!

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: It can take some practice, but small changes in how we speak make a big difference. Give it a try – you can do this!

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: That's okay. It may take time to learn how to do this. After the next instruction you give your child, stop and think how it could be rephrased as a positive instruction. You’ve got this!

rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: That’s great! It might feel a bit awkward at first, but the more you try, the easier it gets. Keep up the excellent effort!
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: It can take some practice, but small changes in how we speak make a big difference. Give it a try – you can do this!
rows.quiz_1_feedback_3: That's okay. It may take time to learn how to do this. After the next instruction you give your child, stop and think how it could be rephrased as a positive instruction. You’ve got this!

rows.media_title: Hear how @data.characters.media_female_3.name learned to give her children positive instructions
rows.media_transcript:
Before, I used to raise my children the way I was raised: I would tell them “don’t do this, don’t do that.” We used to fight a lot, but things have really changed when I learned about giving positive instructions.

Now I focus on the behaviour I want to see, and give clear and simple instructions to my children. It took time to learn to say “please do this” instead of “ don’t do this.” 
My children and even my husband tell me that they love this way of doing things, because now they know what needs to be done. My child said one day “I really love this new mom,” and my own stress levels have come down a lot.
